title: Between 1 April 2018 and 31 March 2019, will an armed group from Nigeria engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Nigeria?
preds: Boko Haram are out of the picture for this one, and good riddance.  However, the logic of the scorers on the Philippines Q suggests that if any Fulani, irrespective of membership in any organized group, kills any non-Fulani, it will count toward a Yes; ditto if any non-Fulani, irrespective of as above, kills a Fulani.  The other possibility is that the scorers will not follow the logic employed on the Philippines Q, in which case it's unlikely any particular group can get its score up high enough.

Over the period April to May 2018, the cumulative civilian death toll in Nigeria stands at 944. Around 136 of these deaths are the result of Boko Haram, while the remainder are attributed to "sectarian actors." https://www.cfr.org/nigeria/nigeria-security-tracker/p29483
Reducing my forecast massively due to: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/733849

@mzapata I am unsure how to forecast. Would Fulani Herder-Farmer violence resolve this question / be considered as systematic killings? Although there is not a clear and overarching political agenda behind the violene afaik, the killings are not unrelated and def. a result of greed and grievance. I'd argue that Fulani attacks should resolve this question, especially in regard to their ethnic dimensions, the reprisal attacks etc. Did the EWP discuss this issue yet? (Need to discuss this in 2017 was lower, as the death toll was too).

KEY ASSUMPTIONS
------------------
1) Boko Haram has killed roughly 900+ people per year for the past two years. CFR's Nigeria Security Tracker attributes to Boko Haram 219 deaths between February and April 2018. The number of annual deaths attributed to BH has declined precipitously since its peak in 2015 2) The group is beset by leadership struggles, fractionalization, declining membership, loss of elite support, and shrinking territory 3) The Nigerian military has been accused of being under-equipped to carry on the fight, but recently the US agreed to begin arms sales to Nigeria. Additionally, the Nigerian military has made significant territorial gains on the battlefield, while BH has gained little new territory. ACLED concludes that the Nigerian military's recent declaration of the defeat of BH "appears to reflect a genuine containment of the insurgency" 4) Despite this loss of territory, BH members become reliant on stealth and blending in with civilians as well as expanding internationally into neighboring countries 5) The Nigerian government and some factions of BH started ceasefire negotiations at the end of March  CONCLUSION
-----------
Boko Haram appears to be on the decline but it still remains a deadly force capable of committing severe atrocities.

This is a hot zone that could blow up anytime. Currently the U.S. military is providing assistance but it was a snatch and grab mission that led to Green Berets being ambushed last month and those intel gathering operations have now been curtailed. The French are mounting the pressure in MALI on the Tureg Alliance and this often portends a increase in operational tempo in the region as a way of relieving Boko Harem when they are under pressure. This time I think we were going to flip the tables, but acted before we had our intel infrastructure completely on line.
I'll defer to my previous comments on the issue: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/585605
